name: Zermatt
fun_fact: Fun fact: Zermatt has banned gasoline vehicles since 1947 to preserve air quality - only electric vehicles, horse-drawn carriages, and bicycles are allowed. The village sits at 1,620m altitude with the iconic Matterhorn (4,478m) towering above. It's one of the world's most expensive ski resorts.

hero_dishes.name: Raclette
hero_dishes.description: Half-wheel of Raclette cheese melted and scraped onto boiled potatoes, pickled onions, and cornichons
hero_dishes.origin_story: Raclette originated in the Valais canton where Zermatt is located. Alpine shepherds would melt cheese by the fire, scraping (racler means 'to scrape') the melted part onto bread. Modern restaurants use electric raclette grills or traditional half-wheels melted tableside. The cheese is nutty, creamy, stretchy. Zermatt locals eat it after skiing.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Chez Vrony (mountain restaurant accessible by cable car), Snowboat (fondue igloo restaurant), or traditional Valais restaurants in Zermatt village

hero_dishes.name: Fondue Valaisanne
hero_dishes.description: Cheese fondue specific to Valais region - blend of local cheeses melted with white wine and kirsch, served with bread cubes
hero_dishes.origin_story: Valais fondue uses local cheeses like Raclette and Gomser, different from classic Swiss fondue. The high altitude and dry climate of Zermatt make cheese fondue especially comforting. Swiss fondue etiquette is serious: stir in figure-8 pattern, never double-dip, if you drop bread you buy drinks. Locals eat it as dinner after a day on the slopes.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Restaurant Whymper-Stube, Cervo Puro, or mountain huts accessible by ski lifts

hero_dishes.name: Cholera (Valais Vegetable Pie)
hero_dishes.description: Savory pie with potatoes, leeks, apples, onions, and cheese in pastry crust - despite the name, it's delicious
hero_dishes.origin_story: The name comes from cholera epidemic in 1830s when villagers had to use whatever ingredients were left during quarantine - potatoes, leeks, cheese. The result was surprisingly good. It became Valais regional specialty. The sweet-savory combination (apples with cheese and potatoes) is uniquely Alpine.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional Valais restaurants in Zermatt, mountain huts, or local bakeries

signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Essential apr√®s-ski drink in Zermatt. After a day skiing under the Matterhorn, skiers gather at outdoor bars drinking gl√ºhwein from ceramic mugs. The spiced wine warms frozen hands and spirits. The mug deposit system encourages lingering. Some bars serve it with a shot of schnapps (J√§gertee).

signature_drinks.name: Williamine (Pear Brandy)
signature_drinks.description: Clear pear brandy from Valais region - aromatic, strong (40% alcohol), with whole pear inside bottle
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Made from Williams pears grown in Valais, Williamine is the regional digestif. The whole pear inside the bottle grows there - farmers place the bottle over the bud on the tree. Locals sip it ice-cold after fondue or raclette. It's smooth, fruity, and deceptively strong.
